Row.Text: The Comanche are a Native American tribe from the Great Plains whose historic territory, known as Comancheria, consisted of present day eastern New Mexico, southeastern Colorado, southwestern Kansas, western Oklahoma, and most of northwest Texas. The Comanche people are federally recognized as the Comanche Nation, headquartered in Lawton, Oklahoma.

The Comanche emerged as a distinct group shortly before 1700, when they broke off from the Shoshone people[14] living along the upper Platte River in Wyoming. In 1680, the Comanche acquired horses from the Pueblo Indians after the Pueblo Revolt.[15] They separated from the Shoshone after this, as the horses allowed them greater mobility in their search for better hunting grounds.[NEWLINE] The horse was a key element in the emergence of a distinctive Comanche culture. It was of such strategic importance that some scholars suggested that the Comanche broke away from the Shoshone and moved southward to search for additional sources of horses among the settlers of New Spain to the south (rather than search for new herds of buffalo.) The Comanche may have been the first group of Plains natives to fully incorporate the horse into their culture and to have introduced the animal to the other Plains peoples.

Quanah Parker was a Comanche chief, a leader in the Native American Church, and the last leader of the powerful Quahadi band before they surrendered their battle of the Great Plains and went to a reservation in Indian Territory. Quanah Parker also led his people on the reservation, where he became a wealthy rancher and influential in Comanche and European American society.

Greetings Quanah Parker, Chief of the Quahadi Comanche. The Comanche broke away from their Shoshone brother, to venture down south to the inhospitable Southern plains of what is now Texas. There the Comanche became the most feared and formidable tribe of the southern plains. Your opponents feared the hordes of the Comanche, that they increase their territory even withen the ever growing presence of Europeans. The Comanche may still be independence today if it wasn't for Outbreaks of smallpox, which took a major toll on the Comanche, whom was soon forced into reservations.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Full Moon will rise soon, and the Comanche are preparing for a raid. Are you, Quanah Parker, ready to lead them into battle? Are you ready to bring glory back to Comancheria? Can you build a civilization that will stand the test of time?
Mounted Units may permanently steal [ICON_RES_HORSE] Horses from a tile containing Horses. Gain [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age point from Horses.

The sweat lodge is a hut, typically dome-shaped and made with natural materials, used by Indigenous peoples of the Americas for ceremonial steam baths and prayer.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There are several styles of structures used in different cultures; these include a domed or oblong hut similar to a wickiup, a permanent structure made of wood and earth, or even a simple hole dug into the ground and covered with planks or tree trunks. Stones are typically heated and then water poured over them to create steam. In ceremonial usage, these ritual actions are accompanied by traditional prayers and songs.
+25% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Person generation, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith, +2 [ICON_HAPPINESS] Happiness. City must border a River or a Lake
+25% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Person generation, +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith, +2 [ICON_HAPPINESS] Happiness. City must border a River or a Lake
Plains Tribes use Tipis on their hunts.
May improve Horses, Cows, Deer, and Bisons. +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture. +1 [ICON_GOLD] with Economics.

Ah, Came to stop our raid?... Oh, Your someone new. Well then, Welcome to Comancheria.
You have destoryed the last of the Comanche. The world shall weep for this lost.
